notes.text:
[**2106-4-15**] 9:11 AM
 HEPATIC                                                         Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83621**]
 Reason: Please perform angio for ? embolization if source of bleedin
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 270
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
 * [**Numeric Identifier 2012**] VISERAL SEL/SUPERSEL A-GRAM     [**Numeric Identifier 17538**] BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION WIT   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 3186**] INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT   [**Numeric Identifier 2009**] INITAL 3RD ORDER ABD/PEL/LOWER   *
 * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY          [**Numeric Identifier 2010**] EA 1ST ORDER ABD/PEL/LOWER EXT   *
 * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE       [**Numeric Identifier 5625**] ADD'L 2ND/3RD ORDER ABD/PEL/LO   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 2012**] VISERAL SEL/SUPERSEL A-GRAM     -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE        *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 2012**] VISERAL SEL/SUPERSEL A-GRAM     -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE        *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 4617**] EA ADD'L VESSEL AFTER BASIC A-  [**Numeric Identifier 4617**] EA ADD'L VESSEL AFTER BASIC A-   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 4617**] EA ADD'L VESSEL AFTER BASIC A-  [**Numeric Identifier 4617**] EA ADD'L VESSEL AFTER BASIC A-   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 2011**] TRANCATHETER EMBOLIZATION       [**Numeric Identifier 3187**] CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 1840**] F/U STATUS INFUSION/EMBO        [**Numeric Identifier 17540**] BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO    *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  54 year old man with 2 indwelling biliary stents and recurrent GI bleeding of
  unclear source
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please perform angio for ? embolization if source of bleeding is identified and
  also assess biliary stents for patency, position, and possible manipulation for
  correction of duodenal erosion
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  54-year-old man with complicated hepatobiliary history including
 CCY c/b gallbladder rupture, and choledochogastric and choledochocutaneous
 fistulas, now with right and left-sided biliary stents, presenting with upper
 GI bleeding of unclear source.  EGD findings suggest stents unlikely to course
 via native upper cbd.  Request to perform angiogram to identify source of
 bleeding and to perform a cholangiogram to evaluate the biliary stents plus
 minus intervention.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 611**] [**Name (STitle) 8814**], Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 331**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 5473**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**]
 performed the procedure.  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 5473**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologists,
 were present throughout the procedure.

 ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under general anesthesia with local
 1% lidocaine used as well.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After explaining the risks, benefits and alternatives
 of the procedure, written informed consent was obtained.  The patient was
 brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table.  The
 right upper abdomen and the right groin were prepped and draped in standard
 sterile fashion.  Preprocedure timeout and huddle were performed per [**Hospital1 184**]
 protocol.
 1.  Right common femoral arterial access.
 2.  SMA and selective IPDA arteriograms.
 3.  Celiac selective left gastric, common hepatic, GDA, right hepatic
 arteriograms.
 4.  Coil embolization of the gastroduodenal artery.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2106-4-15**] 9:11 AM
 HEPATIC                                                         Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83621**]
 Reason: Please perform angio for ? embolization if source of bleedin
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 270
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 5.  [**Name (NI) 83622**] PTC.
 6.  Extension of right hepatic ductal stent.
 7.  Placement of 8 French internal-external biliary drainage catheter.

 Using fluoroscopic and palpatory guidance, the right common femoral artery was
 accessed using a 19-gauge arterial needle, through which [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 89**] wire was
 advanced into the abdominal aorta under fluoroscopic guidance.  Needle was
 exchanged for a 5 French [**Last Name (un) 67**]-Tip sheath which was connected to a continuous
 saline sidearm flush.  A 5 French C2 catheter was then advanced over the
 [**Last Name (un) 89**] wire and used to select the superior mesenteric artery and a selective
 SMA run performed.  No active extravasation or pseudoaneurysm was seen.  There
 was irregularity of the branches coming off the inferior pancreaticoduodenal
 artery.  Celiac arteriography with selectives then performed via the C2
 catheter as described below.  Using Merit microcatheter and Transcend
 microwire the SMA was recatheterized, and IPDA was superselectively
 catheterized and a selective arteriogram performed.  This, however, did not
 demonstrate any active extravasation or pseudoaneurysm formation.  In
 addition, even a 0.016 Transcend wire was unable to traverse the stenotic path
 into this artery. Collaterals arising off the IPDA was also seen contributing
 significantly to the middle colic artery.  As a result embolization was not
 performed at this location.

 The C2 catheter was then used to select the celiac artery ostium and a
 selective celiac arteriogram performed.  The catheter was then advanced into
 the common hepatic and subsequently selective common hepatic, GDA and right
 hepatic arteriograms were performed.  By performing [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 55838**] loop on the C2
 catheter, the left gastric artery ostium was catheterized and a selective left
 gastric arteriogram performed.  No active arterial extravasation was seen.
 After discussing the findings with the surgical team, it was decided to
 perform prophylactic embolization of the gastroduodenal artery.

 The C2 catheter was again advanced into the celiac artery and used to select
 the common hepatic artery.  A 0.035 Glidewire was then navigated into the GDA.
 The C2 catheter was advanced over the Glidewire into the proximal
 gastroduodenal artery.  Using a combination of a Transcend microwire and a
 Merit Maestro microcatheter, GDA was selectively catheterized and the
 microcatheter was advanced into the distal GDA.  Coil embolization of the GDA
 was then performed subsequently by deploying multiple 2-mm, 3-mm and 4-mm
 sized Hilal coils right up to origin of the gastroduodenal artery from the
 common hepatic artery.  Post-embolization common hepatic arteriogram was
 performed confirming no flow through the GDA.  The catheter and sheath were
 removed and hemostasis was achieved by manual compression for 20 minutes.
 Sterile dressings were applied.

 FINDINGS ON THE ARTERIOGRAM:
                                                             (Over)

 [**2106-4-15**] 9:11 AM
 HEPATIC                                                         Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83621**]
 Reason: Please perform angio for ? embolization if source of bleedin
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 270
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 1.  Calcified atherosclerosis of abdominal aorta.
 2.  Celiac common hepatic, left gastric, GDA and right hepatic arteriograms
 revealed no active arterial extravasation or pseudoaneurysm formation. The
 patient is s/p splenectomy.
 3.  Venous phase of SMA run shows prominent mesenteric veins and what appears
 to be recanalization of cavernous transformation of the portal vein with
 hepatopetal flow. Moderate sized esophageal varices also seen.
 4.  Small right hepatic arterio-portal fistula.
 5.  SMA arteriogram reveals small irregular arterial branch coming off the
 IPDA.  Superselective IPDA angiogram performed, which did not show any active
 arterial extravasation.  Collateral branches contributing to the middle colic
 artery seen supplying the watershed region of the splenic flexure, and in view
 of these the IPDA was not embolized.
 6.  Successful microcoil embolization of the gastroduodenal artery with good
 angiographic results.

 Attention was now directed towards performing the PTC.  Under fluoroscopic
 guidance, a 21-gauge Cook needle was used to access the right posterior ductal
 system and a percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram performed.  A peripheral
 right posterior duct was then selected and accessed using a second Cook
 needle.  A 0.018 Headliner wire was advanced through the needle into the right
 hepatic duct.  The Cook needle was exchanged for an AccuStick sheath set.  The
 metal stiffener and inner dilator were removed and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 89**] wire was advanced
 through the sheath into the duodenum.  The AccuStick sheath was then exchanged
 for 6 French [**Last Name (un) 67**]-Tip sheath.  An angled glide catheter was then used to
 exchange the [**Last Name (un) 89**] wire for an Amplatz wire.  A pullback cholangiogram was
 then performed.  Based on the findings of the cholangiogram it was decided to
 extend the right-sided ductal stent.  A marker catheter was advanced over the
 Amplatz wire and after making appropriate measurements, an 8 mm x 60 mm
 Wallstent was advanced over the Amplatz wire.  Proximal end of the stent was
 positioned within the covered stent in the right duct and the distal end of
 the stent was positioned within the third part of duodenum.  The stent was
 then sequentially balloon dilated using 6 mm x 4 cm [**Last Name (un) 19795**] balloon.
 Post-balloon dilatation cholangiogram was performed.  The sheath was then
 removed and a new 8.5 French biliary drainage catheter (which was destrung and
 extra side holes created) was advanced over the Amplatz wire.  Contrast was
 injected confirming intraductal location of the most proximal side holes.  The
 catheter was secured to the skin using 0 silk purse-string suture and another
 0 silk retaining suture.  The catheter was opened to an external drainage bag.
 Sterile dressings were applied.

 FINDINGS:
 1.  Initial spot fluoroscopic image demonstrates indwelling metallic biliary
 stents from the prior procedure with expected unchanged position.
 2.  Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram via right posterior ductal access
                                                             (Over)

 [**2106-4-15**] 9:11 AM
 HEPATIC                                                         Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83621**]
 Reason: Please perform angio for ? embolization if source of bleedin
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 270
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 reveals widely patent indwelling stent with good flow of contrast into the
 duodenum. Crowding of ducts reflects some hepatic atrophy (not new).
 3.  Successful antegrade extension of the right ductal stent by coaxially
 deploying within it an 8 mm x 60 mm Wallstent.
 4.  Placement of 8 French internal-external biliary drainage catheter open to
 internal drainage bag.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well, and there were no post-procedure
 complications.  The patient was transferred to the surgical ICU in stable
 condition.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No active arterial extravasation seen on the celiac and SMA arteriograms.
 Prophylactic coil embolization of the gastroduodenal artery performed with
 good angiographic results.

 2. Successful extension of right hepatic ductal stent by coaxially deploying 8
 mm x 60 mm Wallstent.  8 French internal-external biliary drainage catheter
 was placed, which is open to an external drainage bag.  The catheter may be
 capped after 24 hours if no signs of biliary obstruction or infection develop.

Admission Date:  [**2106-4-14**]              Discharge Date:   [**2106-5-2**]

Date of Birth:  [**2052-2-9**]             Sex:   M

Service: SURGERY

Allergies:
Penicillins

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 5569**]
Chief Complaint:
Recurrent GI bleeding


Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
[**2106-4-18**] Exploratory laparotomy and open gastrotomy, removal of
biliary Wall stents, packing of duodenum
[**2106-4-18**] Coil and Gelfoam embolization of right hepatic artery
branch
pseudoaneurysm.
[**2106-4-15**]  Coil embolization of the gastroduodenal artery.


History of Present Illness:
The pt is a 54yo man with history of recurrent GI bleeding
requiring an extended admission [**5-11**] (EGD noted esophagitis,
healed GEJ ulcer, gastritis, and duodenitis, was treated with
octreotide and protonix gtt) well as a more recent admission
last week during which EGD did not identify active source of
bleeding. He returns today with further bleeding, stating that
he had hematemeis and melena this morning, then became dizzy and
came in for evaluation. NGT lavage was performed with frankly
bloody fluid. Rectal exam performed with dark stool and visible
blood/guaiac positive. Was started on nadolol, carafate, and [**Hospital1 **]
PPI for GI bleeding at last d/c but has not initiated nadolol
due to a pharmacist thinking the nadolol was for HTN and might
possibly be redundant. He has been taking carafate and PPI. The
[**5-11**] admission also notable for surgical resection
choledochocolic fistula with  right hemicolectomy, ileal
transverse colostomy anastomosis, side-to-side gastrojejunostomy
and biliary stenting for choledochocutaneous fistulae.  Has been
doing well since removal of PTC drains last week though notes
mild erythema at lateral drain site.

Past Medical History:
PMH: Ruptured GB c/b recurrent pericholecystic abscesses since
[**1-10**] treated with percutaneous cholecystostomy and multiple
biliary stents, hx CBD/R colonic fistula ([**5-11**]), R colectomy
[**5-11**], partial L nephrectomy for renal clear cell carcinoma
[**1-/2106**], right complete nephrectomy for [**Last Name (un) 42686**] tumor, HTN,
insulin-dependent DMII, PUD, PE/DVT ([**2099**], completed warfarin),
Gout, Hereditary spherocytosis s/p splenectomy, [**Last Name (un) 42686**] tumor s/p
R nephrectomy

PSH: Splenectomy ([**2057**]), R nephrectomy ([**2064**]), Right
hemicolectomy with ileal transverse colostomy anastomosis and
side-to-side gastrojejunostomy [**2105-5-28**], PTBD x 2 (removed last
wk, s/p gelfoam occlusion stent tracts).


Social History:
denies etoh, drugs or tobacco. LiVes alone. Works as a software
consultant in the energy industry. Social History: He works as a
software consultant. Never smoked or drank alcohol. He is
currently on leave from work and living with his mother. [**Name (NI) **]
denied any past exposures to hepatitis or HIV.




Family History:
Family History: He has no biological children. His family
history is significant for hereditary spherocytosis in his
mother and for diabetes mellitus. His father had prostate
cancer. pt states multiple family members have had their
gallbladders out but none were complicated procedures.

Physical Exam:
PE on Admission:
98.2  123  104/60  20  100% Pain 0/10
Gen: Alert, oriented, pleasant, not in distress
CV: RRR, no murmurs
Resp: Lungs clear to auscultation
Abd: Soft, non-tender, non-distended with well-healed incision.
Drain removal site in RUQ non-infected with small hematogenous
oozing and 2cm of granulation tissue.
Rectal: dark stool/visible blood. guaiac positive.


Pertinent Results:

MICRO:
[**4-16**] BCx x2: enterococcus and enterobacter, suscep to vanc and
[**Last Name (un) 2830**]

[**4-20**] urine cx: neg

[**4-25**] blood cx: P
[**4-26**] blood cx: P

IMAGING:
- [**4-17**] Abd Duplex & GB U/S: Coarse echotexture of the liver,
without focal lesions. Extremely limited doppler study. Normal
hepatic vein Doppler. Normal left portal vein. Assessment of the
right portal vein is extremely limited on this study. Previously
seen small hepatic artery- right portal fistula is difficult to
evaluate in this study, please refer to the IR procedure report
on [**4-15**].
- [**4-17**] CTA: No active bleed, ?incr luminal flow in L-side
- [**4-21**] CXR: Continued enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with
pulmonary vascular congestion and layering pleural effusions.
Retrocardiac opacification @left lower lobe
- [**4-28**] CXR: NGT side port and tip within the stomach. Resolution
of pulmonary edema since [**2106-4-22**].

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Hepatobiliary Surgical Service
for evaluation and treatment of UGIB in the setting of known
biliary stents partially extruding through ampulla with
associated duodenal ulceration as well as portal hypertensive
gastropathy. Pt was admitted to the Surgical Intensive Care
Unit, placed on a PPI drip, Foley for hemodynamic monitoring and
serial Hematocrits.  Angio was performed [**4-15**], and his GDA was
embolized. He was transfered to the floor [**4-16**] with stable HCT.
On the morning of [**4-17**] he was noted to have a lower HCT and
tachycardia with BRBPR and he was again transferred to the ICU
for management of an acute GI bleed. He underwent repeat EGD,
which showed extensive clot in the stomach. Unable to ID source
of bleeding, though felt to be from duodenum. He then had
massive UGI bleed, receiving 12u PRBC and becoming unstable. He
then was taken to the operating [****], where a gastrotomy
was created, the stents were taken out through his pylorus, and
the duodenum was packed with surgicel. The abdomen was left
open. He received 34 units perioperatively, as well as profuse
amounts of FFP and cryo. he was taken back to OR for abdominal
closure [**4-20**] and then was transferred back to the floor. He
remained there with a hct in the low 30s with no transfusions x
2 days. Of note, he was found to have enterococcus in his blood,
and so he stayed in house on the floor to receive antibiotics.
On [**4-27**] there was bilious staining noted on the vac. However, a
cholangiogram was not concerning for leak. [**4-27**] Hct was 32.8 and
the pt was asymptomatic all day. However, later in the evening
he vomited blood. At that time, his SBP was 100, HR 120 and the
Vac output became bloody from bilious. [**4-28**] he was transfered
again to the  SICU for hematemesis--mixed dark and bright red
blood per mouth and rectum. An NGT was placed but unable to
lavage due to thick stomach contents. He was monitored on Q2h
hcts and coags and transfused 3uPRBC overnight. HDS. On [**4-29**] he
had 900cc of emesis (dark red blood, most likely old blood) and
remained tachycardic, however his HCT initially remained stable
at 28.0. Later that day he had 600cc dark bloody emesis, RBCs &
FFP were given, trauma line was placed, and emergent endoscopy
was performed. This revealed grade II/III esophageal and gastric
varices. 10 RBC's & 8 FFP were given, as was Activated Factor
VII was administered and he required pressors for SBP support.
On [**4-30**] he came off pressors, and his HCT was stable. He was
started on TPN, however he required massive transfusion that
afternoon after copious hematemesis and melena with a HCT of 15.
He was transfued 22U PRBC, 2FFP, 2plts, 3000mcg factor 7
(40mcg/kg). He was scoped by GI, who placed [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] - noting
possible bleed from both GE junction and duodenum/stomach. Given
his worsening metabolic acidosis, increasing lactate bicarb gtt
& phenylephrine gtt were restarted overnight. He was also
maintained on ARDS protocol on the vent. On [**5-1**] a family
meeting was held and, given the lack of surgical option and the
intractable bleeding, the decision was made to make the pt [**Name (NI) 3225**].
On [**5-2**] he expired with family at the bedside and time of death
was called at 20:34.
[**5-2**]: [**Month/Day (4) 3225**]


Medications on Admission:

(Daily).
2. ursodiol 300 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times

Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO twice a day.

Subcutaneous once a day.

8. Carafate 1 gram Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO four times a
day.
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
9.. multivitamin with iron     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO
once a day: Take separate from Cipro. [**Month (only) 116**] darken stool.

 OTHER EMBO                                                      Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83738**]

 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 210
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************

 * [**Numeric Identifier 2009**] INITAL 3RD ORDER ABD/PEL/LOWER  -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY           *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 2010**] EA 1ST ORDER ABD/PEL/LOWER EXT  -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE        *

 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  54 year old man with GI BLEED
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  identify source, embo if possible
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  54-year-old man with GI bleed, for localization and embolization.

 COMPARISON:  CTA from [**2106-4-17**]; Doppler ultrasound abdomen and pelvis,
 [**2106-4-17**]; hepatic angiography from [**2106-4-15**].

 MEDICATIONS:  Moderate sedation was administered by providing divided doses of
 fentanyl and midazolam throughout the total intraservice time of 2 hours
 during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.
 1% lidocaine was used for local pain control.

 OPERATORS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3268**] [**Name (STitle) 1368**] (fellow) and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 411**] [**Name (STitle) 412**] (attending
 interventional radiologist) was present and supervising throughout the entire
 procedure.

 PROCEDURES:
 1.  The right common femoral arterial access.
 2.  Celiac, common hepatic and subselective right hepatic arteriograms.
 3.  Coil and Gelfoam embolization of right hepatic artery branch
 pseudoaneurysm.
 4.  Post-embolization subselective right hepatic artery and common hepatic
 arteriograms.
 5.  Superior mesenteric arteriogram.

 PROCEDURE:  After discussion of the risks, benefits and alternatives to the
 procedure with the patient, written informed consent was obtained.  The
 patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging
 table.  The right groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2106-4-18**] 2:17 AM
 OTHER EMBO                                                      Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83738**]
 Reason: identify source, embo if possible
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: VISAPAQUE Amt: 210
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 A preprocedure huddle and timeout were performed per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.

 Under fluoroscopic and palpatory guidance, the right common femoral artery was
 accessed over the femoral head using a 19-gauge needle.  A 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 89**] wire
 was advanced into the aorta under fluoroscopic guidance.  A 5 French [**Last Name (un) 67**]-Tip
 sheath was exchanged for the 19-gauge needle and connected to a heparin/saline
 flush.  A C2 Cobra catheter was advanced over the wire, wire removed, and the
 celiac axis selected.  The celiac axis arteriography was performed.  Next, a
 0.035 Glide was advanced into the common hepatic artery, the catheter advanced
 and angiography performed.  Based on the results of these studies a Renegade
 Hi-[**Last Name (un) **] loaded with a combination of a 0.018 Transcend wire and a Fathom
 Steerable wire were used to advance the microcatheter into branches of the
 right hepatic artery.  Subselective angiograms were performed.  Based on the
 results a pseudoaneurysm was coiled with 0.018 2 cm x 3 mm Hilal custom coils
 and a 0.018  6 cm x 5 mm Hilal coils.  Gelfoam embolization was performed to
 near stasis.  Post-procedure common hepatic arteriography demonstrated near
 total occlusion of the pseudoaneurysm.

 C2 catheter was advanced into the superior mesenteric artery ostium and an
 arteriogram performed.  The catheters, wires and sheaths were removed and
 closure of the right common femoral arteriotomy site achieved with manual
 pressure.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no
 immediate post-procedure complications.

 FINDINGS:
 1.  Pre-procedure fluoroscopic spot image demonstrates a nasogastric tube,
 right PTBD, two stents, coils overlying the GDA and radiopaque material, Onyx
 from the previous embolization of the choledochocutaneous fistula.
 2.  Pseudoaneurysm of a branch of the right hepatic artery, leading to likely
 bile duct opacification on selective injection.
 3.  Post-coiling and Gelfoam embolization demonstrated near occlusion of the
 pseudoaneurysm in the proximal right hepatic artery branch.
 4.  No extravasation seen from a superior mesenteric arteriogram.
 5.  Blood pressure, heart rate and pulse is improved post preprocedure.

 IMPRESSION:
 Successful embolization of a right hepatic artery branch pseudoaneurysm using
 a combination of coils and Gelfoam.

notes.text:
[**2106-4-27**] 2:57 PM
 BILIARY CATH CHECK                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83739**]
 Reason: gravity cholangiogram pls. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 557**] to do.
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
 * [**Numeric Identifier 6610**] CHOLANGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C  -78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPE   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 6611**] TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM                                                     *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  54M with ruptured GB c/b pericholecystic abscess and fistulae s/p gastojej,
  biliary stents, R colectomy [**5-11**], partial L nephrectomy [**1-/2106**] readmitted with
  GI bleeding
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  gravity cholangiogram pls. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 557**] to do.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  54-year-old man with prior complicated cholecystitis status post
 multiple and extensive abdominal surgery with choledochogastric and duodenal
 fistulas, and most recently duodenal variceal bleeding status post surgery.
 Now presents for gravity cholangiogram to assess patency of the tube and to
 evaluate for tube position and existing anatomy.

 PHYSICIANS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending
 radiologist.

 PROCEDURE:  Patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  20 cc of
 Optiray contrast was slowly advanced into the existing internal-external
 biliary drain under gravity.  Opacification of the biliary tree and duodenum
 was achieved.

 Gravity cholangiogram demonstrated non-dilated intrahepatic ducts.  There is
 free flow of contrast through the existing tube which was patent.  The tube
 itself was positioned through the right intrahepatic ducts through the
 choledocho proximal duodenal fistula with the catheter pigtail positioned
 within the stomach.  Contrast flowed freely and quickly through the
 choledochoduodenal fistula, with preferential flow into the stomach, though
 some contrast is seen filling the second and third parts of the duodenum as
 well.  Small amount of contrast is seen pooling at the level of the
 choledochoduodenal fistula where there was a previous choledochoenteric
 connection.  However, no contrast is seen filling a choledochoenteric fistula.
 Contrast is not seen filling what is thought to be native CBD, though given
 the non-dilatation of the intrahepatic system, filling of this channel is
 unlikely.  Multiple projections were obtained which confirmed these findings.

 Following completion of gravity cholangiogram, the catheter was flushed and
 reattached to external bag drainage.

 IMPRESSION:  Gravity cholangiogram demonstrates that the internal-external
 biliary drain tip is positioned in the stomach.  The remaining anatomy and
 non-dilated intrahepatic ducts correspond to previously known findings of a
 choledochoduodenal fistula.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2106-4-27**] 2:57 PM
 BILIARY CATH CHECK                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 83739**]
 Reason: gravity cholangiogram pls. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 557**] to do.
 Admitting Diagnosis: UPPER GI BLEED
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
